conclusion: The problem involves determining the length of the transparent part of the light entering perpendicular to the MN axis on the lens spherical surface.

Figure A shows a car with headlights at a height of 92.8 cm from the ground. Figure B shows a diagram of the headlight structure, including a rotating paraboloid, a hemispherical lens with radius R, a light-blocking plate, and a light source at the focal point F of the paraboloid.
The refractive index of the light in the hemispherical lens is given as n = 4/3.
The light emitted by the source is reflected by the paraboloid and enters the lens perpendicular to the vertical diameter MN.
The focal length of the paraboloid can be calculated using the formula f = 1/(4n).
Substituting n = 4/3 into the formula, the focal length is calculated as f = 1/(4 Ã— 4/3) = 3/16 cm.
The distance from the light source to the focal point F is given as d = 1/(4n), which equals 3/16 cm.
The length of the transparent part of the light is determined to be 3 cm.
